required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Effect of High Rebound Mattress Toppers on Sleep and Sleep-Related Symptoms
clinical_study.official_title: Effect of High Rebound Mattress Toppers on Sleep and Sleep-Related Symptoms

brief_summary.textblock:
The purpose of the study is to evaluate effects of high rebound mattress toppers (i.e., airweave®) on sleep and sleep-related symptoms.
The study will compare effects of use of high rebound mattress toppers versus use of low rebound mattress toppers on sleep and sleep related symptoms and core body temperature during diagnostic sleep studies.

primary_outcome.description: Sleep efficiency is total sleep time divided by time in bed. All data were collected through the PSG data that were retrieved from the patients' medical records after completion of the recordings and analysis by the sleep technologists.
The amount of time from lights off to falling asleep.

primary_outcome.measure: Wake After Sleep Onset (WASO) Assessed by PSG
primary_outcome.description: Total amount of minutes awake after the first sleep epoch.

primary_outcome.measure: Percentage of Time in Bed During Each Sleep Stage

primary_outcome.description: Number of times participant changed position during the sleep recording.

primary_outcome.measure: Apnea Hypopnea Index Assessed by PSG
primary_outcome.description: The number of apneas or hypopneas recorded during the study per hour of sleep.
Number of times participant had periodic leg movements during the sleep recording

primary_outcome.measure: Mean EEG Delta Spectral Power Per Second Over 90 Mins From Lights Off Between 0-360 Minutes After Lights Off
primary_outcome.description: EEG data collected from the electrode in position C2

secondary_outcome.description: Difference in core body temperature changes of the high and low rebound mattress toppers at sleep onset and during sleep. The core body temperature will be monitored every minute throughout the night.
visual analog scale of sleep was used for evaluation of subjective sleep quality. Scale ranged from 0 cm (very bad) to 10 cm (very good).
visual analog scale of performance was used for evaluation of subjective performance quality. Scale ranged from 0 cm (very bad) to 10 cm (very good).
visual analog scale of mood was used for evaluation of subjective mood. Scale ranged from 0 cm (very bad) to 10 cm (very good).

arm_group.description: sleep with mattress topper during overnight diagnostic sleep study
sleep with mattress topper during overnight diagnostic sleep study

intervention.description: Patients will sleep on this mattress topper during their diagnostic sleep study.
Patients will sleep on this mattress topper during their diagnostic sleep study.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Adults Age 18-65 who are scheduled for a diagnostic sleep study at the Stanford Sleep Clinic for sleep disorders (including but not limited to, insomnia, Sleep Apnea or other sleep disorder symptoms).
Exclusion Criteria:
- Individuals with a history of having difficulty swallowing food or large capsules. We will not be able to enroll individuals with any known or suspected obstructive disease of the gastrointestinal tract including, but not limited to esophageal stricture, diverticulosis and inflammatory bowel disease (IBD), peptic ulcer disease, Crohn's disease, ulcerative colitis, previous gastrointestinal surgery.
- Individuals who are pregnant.
- Individuals who are unable to provide informed consent (i.e. decisionally impaired).

responsible_party.investigator_title: Professor, Psychiatry and Behavioral Sciences, Stanford University School of Medicine

participant_flow.recruitment_details: Participants were recruited from individuals who were scheduled for an overnight PSG study as part of their regular care at the Stanford Sleep clinic.
participant_flow.pre_assignment_details: 4 participants were enrolled but not randomized to a study arm.

group.title: Low Rebound Mattress Toppers
group.description: Participants in arm 1 slept on low rebound mattress toppers (Topper Deluxe 3.5, TEMPUR-SEALY Japan Ltd., Kobe, Japan) placed on top of standard mattresses equipped at the Stanford Sleep Clinic.

group.title: High Rebound Mattress Toppers
group.description: Participants in arm 2 slept on high rebound mattress toppers (airweave® toppers, airweave inc., Tokyo, Japan) placed on top of standard mattresses equipped at the Stanford Sleep Clinic.

measure.title: Core Body Temperature

measure.population: Participants with non missing data, who completed the study during the night, and did not initiate CPAP or biPAP during the study were included in the analysis.

analysis.groups_desc: Implemented two-way mixed ANOVA with time as within-subject variable and topper type as between-subject variable. This is to compare the difference in core body temperature trend over time between the two study arms. Interaction between time and topper type on CBT was calculated.

Implemented two-way mixed ANOVA with time as within-subject variable and topper type as between-subject variable. This is to see the effect over time from both study arms on CBT. Main effect of time on CBT.

Implemented two-way mixed ANOVA with time as within-subject variable and topper type as between-subject variable. This is to see the effect of the intervention on CBT including all time points. Main effect of topper type on CBT.

outcome.title: Visual Analog Scale of Sleep
outcome.description: visual analog scale of sleep was used for evaluation of subjective sleep quality. Scale ranged from 0 cm (very bad) to 10 cm (very good).
outcome.population: Participants with non missing data, who completed the study during the night, and did not initiate CPAP or biPAP during the study were included in the analysis.

certain_agreements.pi_employee: All Principal Investigators ARE employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: There is NOT an agreement between Principal Investigators and the Sponsor (or its agents) that restricts the PI's rights to discuss or publish trial results after the trial is completed.
